Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A surprise, tie-breaking vote on a critical piece of legislation is happening in the next hour, and you must immediately contact the undecided representative.
Story:
I stared at my laptop, the Slack notifications piling up. The product manager pinged me again: “We need your input on the API design before noon. The other teams can’t move forward without it.” My calendar was already blocked for a cross-team call in fifteen minutes. I knew how much everyone was counting on me to clarify the technical details—if I didn’t, the whole project could stall.

Just then, my phone buzzed with an urgent message from my activist group. The state legislature was holding a surprise vote on the environmental bill we’d been fighting for all year. The outcome hinged on one undecided representative, and I was the only one with a personal connection. “You have to call now,” the message read. “This is our shot.”

My heart pounded. I could almost hear the clock ticking, each second pulling me in two directions. My team needed me to keep the project on track, but my cause needed me to make a difference—right now. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, and I didn’t know which one I’d let down.
